abstract: JPMorgan Chase is using its checkbook to try to mend frayed relations with the government. | The age of the hostile takeover appears to be ending. | The Fabrice Tourre case is going to a jury on Wednesday. | Little-known private databases can effectively blacklist Americans from the mainstream financial system.

lead_paragraph: JPMorgan Chase is using its checkbook to try to mend frayed relationships with the government, Jessica Silver-Greenberg and Ben Protess report in DealBook. But the new and conciliatory approach is yielding mixed results. “Government officials, stung by the bank’s past displays of hubris, may drive up the price of settlements or resist the overtures altogether.”
